Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff Sarah Thompson (“Plaintiff”) brings this action against Defendant William Carter (“Defendant”) for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable for actual damages or three times the monthly rent, whichever is greater, in addition to attorneys’ fees and costs.

Massachusetts General Laws ch. 186, \u00.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws ch. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment).

Massachusetts General Laws ch. 111, \u00.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws ch. 111, § 127A (requirement for habitable housing conditions).

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005) (standard for breach of quiet enjoyment).
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment and articulates the applicable standard—i.e., that it protects tenants from serious interference with their tenancy and generally requires landlord notice and at least negligent failure to alleviate the condition. While the case ultimately finds no breach on its facts, it clearly restates and applies the governing standard, so it is a proper citation for the standard for breach of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition … and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (implied warranty of habitability).
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) squarely discusses replacing caveat emptor with a new rule imposing landlord obligations for habitable premises and expressly frames the tenants’ theory as an “implied warrantee of habitability.” Although the author disagrees with the majority’s precise formulation, he accepts that the court’s opinion adopts an implied warranty of fitness/habitability and concurs in the key remedial consequence (rent measured by value of premises given code violations). Thus, the case is correctly cited as a leading Massachusetts authority recognizing an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Having thus failed to qualify for the defence which would otherwise have been available to them under § 8A, the tenants ask this court to give them relief by holding (a) that the landlord impliedly warranted the fitness of their apartments for habitation, (b) that the landlord violated the warranty, and (c) that the landlord’s obligation to comply with the warranty and their obligation to pay their rent are mutually interdependent. … I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule … that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement … that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy….’”}

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (tenant remedies for breaches of quiet enjoyment).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses tenant remedies for breaches of quiet enjoyment. The SJC analyzes G.L. c. 186, § 14, holds that pervasive criminal activity in common areas can constitute a serious interference with quiet enjoyment, and explains that tenants may obtain damages and injunctive relief if the housing authority fails to take reasonable measures. Thus, Doe is proper authority for the availability and scope of tenant remedies for breaches of quiet enjoyment in the context of inadequate security/criminal activity on the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, 41.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action… then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 358 Mass. 214 (1970.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 358 Mass. 214 (1970) (landlord’s duty under the covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 358 Mass. 214 (1970.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns Gloucester taxpayers challenging a municipal acquisition of a school under special enabling legislation. It discusses statutory authority, municipal finance limits, and G.L. c. 40, § 53, but does not involve a landlord‑tenant relationship, a lease, or any covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be authority for a landlord’s duty under the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 358 Mass. 214 (1970.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs, taxable inhabitants of the city of Gloucester (city), brought this bill under G. L. c. 40, § 53, to enjoin the city from purchasing or renovating land and buildings in the city known as St. Peter’s High School… The short answer to the allegations of illegality… is that the special statute (St. 1970, c. 87) makes compliance with §§ 30 and 34 of G. L. c. 43 unnecessary.”

Linardon v. Boston Housing Authority, 76.raw_text: Linardon v. Boston Housing Authority, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 1123 (2010)
Linardon v. Boston Housing Authority, 76.proposition: Linardon v. Boston Housing Authority, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 1123 (2010) (landlord liability for failure to provide essential services).

Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 9.raw_text: Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 977 (1986)
Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 9.proposition: Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 977 (1986) (obligation to provide heat under quiet enjoyment).
Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 9.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about evidentiary rulings at trial and potential judicial punishment for exercising the right to a jury trial. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or any obligation to provide heat. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for an obligation to provide heat under the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Farnsworth v. Towes, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 9.relevant_excerpt: A judge may not punish a defendant for the exercise of his constitutional right to have his guilt decided after a trial by jury. See Commonwealth v. Souza, 390 Mass. 813, 818 (1984); Longval v. Meachum, 693 F.2d 236, 238 (1st Cir. 1982), cert. denied, 460 U.S. 1098 (1983).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (availability of treble damages for breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, including its remedies provision, and explains that the statute allows a tenant to recover either “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” plus costs and attorneys’ fees. It further discusses the “triple rent” (three months’ rent) alternative, its purpose, and limits on repeated use, thereby directly addressing the availability and operation of treble-rent damages under § 14. Thus the case is proper authority for the availability of treble damages for breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “A landlord that violates § 14 is subject to a fine or imprisonment, and is liable to its tenants for ‘actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,’ plus costs and attorneys’ fees. … Triple rent damages, as the judge correctly instructed the jury, are appropriate only when they exceed actual and consequential damages. G. L. c. 186, § 14. … We held in Darmetko that a tenant could not recover three months’ rent for each month during which the landlord permitted a violation to continue.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (landlord’s liability for tenant health-related damages).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The case squarely concerns a landlord’s liability to a tenant for harms arising from substandard conditions and wrongful conduct. The SJC affirmed substantial damages, including trebled Chapter 93A damages, for (1) diminution in value of the apartment due to breach of the implied warranty of habitability and (2) severe emotional distress intentionally inflicted by the landlord in the course of the tenancy. Thus it is appropriate authority for the general proposition that a landlord may be liable for tenant health-related (especially emotional/mental health) damages arising from habitability violations and related misconduct.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “On the G.L. c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability… we conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A.”
